subject: BoJ to Release Summary of Opinions from the April 26th-27th meeting at 0050BST/1850CDTâ€¦
content:
The BoJ kept monetary policy unchanged at that meeting as expected with NIRP held at -0.10% and 10yr JGB yield target held at around 0%, while the decision was made by 8-1 vote with Kataoka the dissenter again.

The meeting was the first to include newly appointed BoJ Deputy Governors Amamiya and Wakatabe, although the main surprise was that the BoJ removed reference to achieving the 2% CPI target around FY19. Furthermore, the BoJ stated that risks to economy balanced for FY2018 but are skewed to downside for FY2019.

Outlook Report

Real GDP
- Raised fiscal 2018 forecast to 1.6% from 1.4%.
- Raised fiscal 2019 forecast to 0.8% from 0.7%.
- Set fiscal 2020 forecast at 0.8%.

Core CPI
- Affirmed fiscal 2018 forecast at 1.4%.
- Affirmed fiscal 2019 forecast at 1.8% (excluding effects of sales tax hike).
- Set fiscal 2020 forecast at 1.8%

ASIA-PAC

RBNZ Interest Rate Decision (May) 1.75% vs. Exp. 1.75% (Prev. 1.75%). (Newswires)
RBNZ said that it expects to maintain OCR at this expansionary level for a considerable time and that current level is best to maximize sustainable employment and stable inflation, while it also noted the next direction in rates is equally a hike or cut.
RBNZ said domestic economic growth is robust, while it cited subdued wages, low food & import price inflation for low inflation. RBNZ also maintained forecasts for where it sees OCR through to September 2019 in which it OCR estimates were kept at 1.8% for September 2018 and June 2019, while the estimate for September 2019 was maintained at 1.90%.

US Wholesale Inventory, R MM (Mar) 0.3% vs. Exp. 0.6% (Prev. 0.5%)


MARKET RECAP

US equity markets jumped higher, in line with energy prices, amid broad-based gains across most sectors. The energy sector outperformed on the back of higher oil prices, with Exxon (XOM) and Chevron (CVX) amongst outperformers in the DJI. As markets saw a risk on tone the defensive nature of utilities led to the sector being one of the largest underperformers among with the telecom sector. Stock specifics were dominated by M&A and earnings today, TripAdvisor (TRIP) massively beat EPS expectations which led to the stock closing higher by more than 20%. Coty (COTY) also reported earnings where its EPS was weaker than the previous year, and it also saw weaker than expected consumer product results which overall led to the stock closing lower by ~10%. In M&A news Vodafone (VOD LN) agreed to purchase some of Liberty Global’s (LBTYA) European assets for USD 22.7bln, however the deal still requires approval from regulators and many expect this process to be lengthy, LBTYA saw intraday lows of 14% on Wednesday. Focus also lied on Wal-Mart (WMT), who confirmed it is to acquire USD 16bln stake in Flipkart and as a result, forecasts a FY19 EPS cut between 25c and 30c if the deal closes in Q2. During trading hours, it was announced that Sears Holdings (SHLD) teamed up with Amazon (AMZN) to make tire purchases and installations easier for its customers, this led to SHLD spiking as much as 25% higher, and as a result shares in auto-part makers such as Monro (MNRO) spiked lower. SPX +0.97% at 2698 , NDX +1.10% at 6893, DJI +0.80% at 24543.

Treasury yields were higher across the curve with 5yr, 10yr and 30yr up by c.3bps. The 10yr yield hit session highs at 3.014% on Wednesday and held just above 3%, shrugging off soft PPI figures and after the 10yr auction tailed by 0.1bps. The yield came in at 2.995%, the highest since January 2014. US 10yr T-Notes futures settle 8 ticks lower at 119-8+.

US MARKET WRAP 9 May 2018: Crude continues to climb ahead of US sanctions on Iran
content:
• * SNAP-SHOT: Equities higher, Treasuries down, DXY mixed, Crude higher
  • * REAR-VIEW: Softer US PPI, Fed’s Bostic, earnings from DIS, TRIP
  • * AHEAD: RBNZ rate decision, Chinese CPI US CPI, BoE rate decision and minutes, earnings from BT LN, NVDA

* IRAN NUCLEAR DEAL: Iran’s leader Rouhani expressed his commitment to keep the pact with members of the P5+1. Similarly, French President Macron told Iran's Rouhani he wants to keep the nuclear accord alive, but that Iran must respect the accord in its entirety. US Treasury Secretary Mnuchin noted the US will be working with allies on a comprehensive deal, stating that firms can seek waivers or special licences to operate in Iran.

*FED SPEAK: Fed’s Bostic (voter, dovish) said inflation is likely to run above 2% for a while and noted overshooting is not a problem.

* EQUITIES: SPX +0.97% at 2698 , NDX +1.10% at 6893, DJI +0.80% at 24543 .  SECTORS: Cons Cyclicals: +0.22%, Cons Non-Cyclicals: -0.17%, Energy: +1.90%, Financials: +1.17%, Health Care: +0.53%, Industrials: +0.96%, Materials: +1.27%, Technology: +1.41%, Telecoms: -1.11%, Utilities: -0.80%.

US equity markets jumped higher, in line with energy prices, amid broad-based gains across most sectors.

The energy sector outperformed on the back of higher oil prices, with Exxon (XOM) and Chevron (CVX) amongst outperformers in the DJI. As markets saw a risk on tone the defensive nature of utilities led to the sector being one of the largest underperformers among with the telecom sector.

Stock specifics were dominated by M&A and earnings today, TripAdvisor (TRIP) massively beat EPS expectations which led to the stock closing higher by more than 20%. Coty (COTY) also reported earnings where its EPS was weaker than the previous year, and it also saw weaker than expected consumer product results which overall led to the stock closing lower by ~10%. In M&A news Vodafone (VOD LN) agreed to purchase some of Liberty Global’s (LBTYA) European assets for USD 22.7bln, however the deal still requires approval from regulators and many expect this process to be lengthy, LBTYA saw intraday lows of 14% on Wednesday. Focus also lied on Wal-Mart (WMT), who confirmed it is to acquire USD 16bln stake in Flipkart and as a result, forecasts a FY19 EPS cut between 25c and 30c if the deal closes in Q2. During trading hours, it was announced that Sears Holdings (SHLD) teamed up with Amazon (AMZN) to make tire purchases and installations easier for its customers, this led to SHLD spiking as much as 25% higher, and as a result shares in auto-part makers such as Monro (MNRO) spiked lower.

* CRUDE: WTI crude futures settle higher by USD 2.08 at USD 71.14/bbl, Brent crude futures settle higher by USD 2.36 at USD 77.21/bbl.

Oil prices climbed on Wednesday as markets await for the ‘highest level’ of sanctions to be imposed on Tehran, following the US withdrawal from the Iran nuclear deal. Further upside in prices was seen after the EIA reported a bigger than expected drawdown in headline crude and sharp drops across the products stockpiles, though those gains only held temporarily. An OPEC source, in response to the US exit from the pact, noted Saudi has enough oil production to keep oil markets stable, but will not act singlehandedly to offset a possible shortage as any decision to adjust output should be driven by a potential physical shortage or reduction in production from any supply source, not Iran. Iraq oil minister Luaibi said OPEC will discuss shortfalls in oil output whilst the Saudi Energy Minister iterated similar words to yesterday, saying he will work closely with OPEC and non-OPEC members to mitigate effects of supply shortages.

* TREASURIES: US 10yr T-Notes futures settle 8 ticks lower at 119-8+.

Treasury yields were higher across the curve with 5yr, 10yr and 30yr up by c.3bps. The 10yr yield hit session highs at 3.014% on Wednesday and held just above 3%, shrugging off soft PPI figures and after the 10yr auction tailed by 0.1bps. The yield came in at 2.995%, the highest since January 2014.

*FOREX: *DXY: The index pulled back from latest new 2018 peaks a few points over 93.400 to sub-93.000 levels, with Dollar pairings retracing recent moves, or consolidating, with the notable exception of USDJPY that remains bid over 109.50. Sub-forecast US PPI and wholesale inventories/sales also weighing along with general profit-taking, assuming the tide is not turning completely for the USD.

*CAD: The Loonie is leading broader G10 recovery gains vs the Greenback (while the Lira is outperforming in the EM area, albeit with the aid of official intervention and still awaiting news from a Government and CBRT meeting on the TRY and economy) on the back of sharply higher crude prices post-confirmation of the US exiting from the Iranian nuclear deal, and on a decent Canadian data beat (building approvals). USDCAD has reversed from 1.3000 peaks posted just 24 hours ago to sub-1.2900 and may re-test support around 1.2850 that also coincides/aligns with the 50 DMA.

*NZD: Kiwi has almost recovered the 0.7000 handle amidst supportive cross flows (JPY and to a lesser extent AUD). Looking ahead, RBNZ policy meeting could provide the next independent driver for the NZD – full previews available via our Research Suite in the Central Bank section.

*AUD, EUR, CHF: Narrowly mixed vs the Dollar, but off worst levels, with AUDUSD looking more comfortable above 0.7450 against the backdrop of firmer oil/commodities, while EURUSD survived a test of demand ahead of 1.1800 at a fresh YTD low around 1.1823 to squeeze back up towards 1.1900 where a very large (2bln) option expiry rolls off tomorrow. The Franc is marginally underperforming within a 1.0000-55 range vs the USD and EURCHF back over 1.1900.

*SEK, NOK: Both largely shrugged off mixed CPI (headline and core) data to extend recent rallies, and with the SEK outpacing its Scandi neighbour on Swedish stock dividend day – EURSEK down to 10.3170 and EURNOK to 9.5660 approximately at various stages.

*COMING-UP: *RBNZ Monetary Policy Decision, due on 10th May at 22:00BST. The RBNZ policy decision is due later in which expectations are one-sided for the RBNZ to keep rates unchanged with all 16 economists surveyed unanimously forecasting the central bank to maintain the Official Cash Rate at 1.75% where it has been since September 2016. The meeting will also include a Monetary Policy Statement press conference and is the first under newly appointed Governor Adrian Orr who took over from Acting Governor Spencer in March. For the full preview click here.

*BoE Monetary Policy Decision, Minutes and Quarterly Inflation Report at 12:00BST (07:00ET), Press Conference with Governor Carney at 12:30BST (07:30ET). The BoE is expected to keep monetary policy instruments unchanged; vote split expected to be 7-2. Of the 41 analysts surveyed by Reuters, 39 expected the MPC to stand pat on rates with just two looking for a hike. The MPC are set to cut forecasts for both inflation and growth given the soft start to the year for the UK economy. For the full preview click here.

AUCTION PREVIEW: US to sell USD 25bln 10-year notes

The US Treasury increased the auction sizes at the quarterly refunding announcement and will auction USD 73bln in 3-year notes (USD 31bln, yesterday), 10-year notes (USD 25bln, today) and 30-year bonds (USD 17bln, Thursday) this week. With a total of USD 39.1bln maturing on 15th May, the auctions will raise USD 33.9bln in the week. The bidding deadline for the auction is 1800BST (1300 eastern time) with results expected shortly after.

Last month’s 10-year note auction was not received particularly well; the auction was covered just 2.46x, below the 6-auction average of 2.49x and the auctioned tailed by 0.5bps. Dealers were also left with a higher than average proportion of the issuance at 38.4%. Of the last six auctions, three have tailed, two have stopped through the WI at the bidding deadline and one has stopped on the screws.

subject: Fixed and FX latest: bonds bounce, but Dollar deflated post-PPI
content: Bunds and Gilts have pared more losses in wake of weaker than expected US PPI, with the former within a handful of ticks from flat and the latter reducing its arrears to around ¼ point from not far off double that at one stage. However, the Usd remains hemmed to the lower end of the day’s range (DXY between 93.420 and 92.917) for obvious reasons, and handing back more of its recent gains to the Loonie especially as the Cad is not only boosted by the rally in oil prices, but also much better than forecast Canadian building permits after yesterday’s miss on housing starts.

subject: RANsquawk Daily US Opening News - 9th May 2018
content:
To download the report, please click here
If you would like to subscribe to receive the research sheets directly in your inbox, you can no do so under the Research Suite section of the portal.
To subscribe simply check the box next to "Email these reports" under the desired category.

  • WTI breaks USD 71/BBL and Brent over 77/BBL as US pulls out of Iran nuclear accord
  • USD firm above 93.000 as US 10 year yield revisits 3%
  • Looking ahead, highlights include DoEs, Fed’s Bostic, RBNZ and US 10yr Auction

ASIA-PAC

Asia stocks traded mixed after a lacklustre lead from Wall St and as markets digested US President Trump’s decision to withdraw from the Iran nuclear agreement which in turn underpinned oil prices. ASX 200 (+0.2%) was kept afloat as energy names coat-tailed on the upside in oil, although gains were limited by weakness in financials after Australia’s largest lender CBA reported earnings. Elsewhere, Nikkei 225 (-0.4%) failed to benefit from JPY weakness and traded subdued, in which electricity names took a power dive on the higher input costs, while both Shanghai Comp. (+0.1%) and Hang Seng (+0.5%) were initially weaker after a daily net liquidity drain by the PBoC and the verbal spat between US and China envoys at the WTO. However, Chinese markets later recovered with Hong Kong leading the rebound as money market rates eased, in which the 1-month HIBOR declined for a 6th consecutive session. Finally, 10yr JGBs were uneventful despite the cautious risk tone and BoJ’s presence in the market for over JPY 1tln in 1yr-10yr JGBs. This was amid gains in yields which tracked upside in their US counterparts with the US 10yr yield homing in again on the 3.000% level.

PBoC injected CNY 60bln via 7-day and CNY 40bln via 14-day reverse repos for a net daily drain of CNY 100bln. (Newswires)

PBoC set CNY mid-point at 6.3733 (Prev. 6.3674)

GEOPOLITICS

Mexico proposed a 70% regional content requirement for autos in response to US proposal, according to sources. (Newswires)

US Secretary of State Pompeo is expected to return from North Korea with 3 detainees, according to South Korean press reports. (Newswires)

IRAN NUCLEAR DEAL

US Treasury Secretary Mnuchin says will be working with allies on a comprehensive deal, also states that firms can seek waivers or special licences to operate in Iran. (Newswires)

Iranian parliament is set to vote on "proportional and reciprocal" action vs. the US after leaving the nuclear pact. (Newswires)

Iranian deputy oil minister says the nuclear deal can exist without the US. (Newswires)

EU/UK/US

Italian Foreign ministry’s secretary general Belloni is seen as the PM and Bank of Italy’s Rossi as finance minister as part of a transitional government via Repubblica. (Newswires)

Swedish CPI YY (Apr) 1.7% vs. Exp. 1.7% (Prev. 1.9%)

Norwegian CPI YY (Apr) 2.4% vs. Exp. 2.3% (Prev. 2.2%)

EQUITIES

Major European bourses are trading mostly higher (Eurstoxx 50 +0.3%), with outperformance in the FTSE MIB . UK’s FTSE 100 (+0.5%) is buoyed by energy names amid higher oil prices post-Trump (Shell +2.4% and BP +2.1%). On the downside, Peugeot (-1.4%), Renault (-1.0%) and Airbus (-1.1%) are at the foot of the CAC 40 on their ties to Iran. Moving onto independent factors, Imperial Brands (+4.7%), Siemens (+4.5%) and Heidelbergcement (+1.4%) are higher following promising earnings while Compass Group (-6.1%) and Prosiebensat (-9.4%) are taking a hit on dissapointing metrics. Burberry (-6.2%) is lagging on the FTSE 100 after Belgian tycoon Albert Frère is to sell his whole GBP 520mln shareholding in the company.

FX

USD

The Dollar’s bull run continues and the index has duly posted another new 2018 peak in the process just above 93.400 and inching closer to the well-flagged next key technical resistance level at 93.522. This comes amidst broad-based Greenback gains, albeit with Turkey’s beleaguered Lira regaining some poise on increased efforts by the CBRT to stem the tide via direct intervention and ahead of a midday (BST) meeting between the PM and Economy Ministry to discuss currency market developments and the overall state of the economy (Usd/Try back below 4.3000 from 4.3700+ at one stage).

JPY

The biggest G10 loser as the Buck extends its winning streak, with reaction to US President Trump’s withdrawal from the Iranian nuclear accord and threat of severe sanctions largely confined to crude that has spiked higher, and limited risk-aversion or contagion thus far. Hence, Usd/Jpy as bounced firmly from sub-109.00 lows above 109.50 and towards recent peaks just above 110.00, with the 200 DMA and a key Fib (around 110.19 and 110.24 respectively) also lying in wait beyond the big figure.

AUD/CHF

Both around 0.2-0.25% lower vs the Usd, and with the former at risk of losing 0.7400+ status, while the latter is revisiting highs within a 1.0000-50 band despite the Franc maintaining momentum vs the Eur below 1.1900.

EUR

Yet more bearish fundamentals (via Italian and French data misses) to compound the positional and Dollar related downside for the single currency below 1.1850, and having relinquished 1.1900 on Tuesday there is little in the way of technical support before 1.1800 aside from a late December 2017 low (1.1812), though the round number may offer some sentimental respite given that a major Fib sits just below (1.1790).

NZD/GBP/CAD

All holding up relatively well in the face of almost relentless Usd buying (or net daily advances at least), with the Kiwi above 0.6950 ahead of the RBNZ policy gathering tonight and amidst some Nzd/Jpy buy-stops tripped overnight by algos. Cable is keeping afloat of 1.3500 before BoE ‘super’ Thursday as Gbp/Jpy rebounds sharply and further over 148.00 and Eur/Gbp retreats to sub-0.8750, while the Loonie is deriving support from oil prices at fresh post-2014 peaks to ease back from yesterday’s near 1.3000 highs.

SEK/NOK

The Scandi Crowns showed scant reaction to Swedish and Norwegian inflation reports that were in line or slightly softer overall, with the Sek actually extending gains vs the Eur and Nok on tax payment deadline day (former pair as low as 10.4130).

FIXED INCOME

The catalysts are pretty well defined and wide-ranging from supply to oil-fuelled inflation on US-Iran discord, and the technical landscape is also becoming more negative as Bunds edge close to a major chart support level at a fresh Eurex intraday low of 158..52 (-33 ticks on the day) and Gilts breach their nearest downside objective, albeit just and not yet convincingly at 121.67 (-47 ticks). In fact, although Gilts are still lagging on the day, futures briefly gleaned more support on supply grounds vs Bunds as the DMO’s 10 year tap was relatively well received vs Germany’s 2048 offering that only drew enough bids to cover around 2/3rd of the total amount, and then only just. The respective 10 year debt futures are now circa 36 ticks and ¼ point below previous settlement levels, but 11 and 8 ticks off worst levels. Meanwhile, US Treasuries are just a few ticks off overnight session lows and the curve is steeper as long bond losses approach one full point and the 10 year yield sits firmly at 3%.

COMMODITIES

Oil prices have continued upwards on Wednesday after President Trump confirmed the withdrawal of the US from the Iran nuclear agreement and imposing of sanctions on the nation; WTI and Brent June ’18 futures at USD 71.00 (+2.8%) and USD 76.89 (+2.7%) respectively. Said sanctions could lead to the reduction of oil exports by 200-500k BPD over the next 6 months for the middle-eastern nation, according to UBS.

Gold prices have continued the slide seen on Tuesday (-0.58%), as the USD held strong on higher treasury yields.

Copper currently up 0.4% at USD 6773.50/tonne as Chinese demand remains strong. This demand is not seen in Chinese rebar however, which is currently down for the fourth straight Wednesday, at USD 559.90/t

EU MID-SESSION UPDATE : Brent barrels past USD 77/BBL as US withdraws from Iran nuclear accord
content:
EQUITIES

Major european bourses are trading mostly higher (Eurstoxx 50 +0.3%), with outperformance in the FTSE MIB . UK’s FTSE 100 (+0.5%) is buoyed by energy names amid higher oil prices post-Trump (Shell +2.4% and BP +2.1%). On the downside, Peugeot (-1.4%), Renault (-1.0%) and Airbus (-1.1%) are at the foot of the CAC 40 on their ties to Iran. Moving onto independent factors, Imperial Brands (+4.7%), Siemens (+4.5%) and Heidelbergcement (+1.4%) are higher following promising earnings while Compass Group (-6.1%) and Prosiebensat (-9.4%) are taking a hit on dissapointing metrics. Burberry (-6.2%) is lagging on the FTSE 100 after Belgian tycoon Albert Frère is to sell his whole GBP 520mln shareholding in the company.

FX

USD

The Dollar’s bull run continues and the index has duly posted another new 2018 peak in the process just above 93.400 and inching closer to the well-flagged next key technical resistance level at 93.522. This comes amidst broad-based Greenback gains, albeit with Turkey’s beleaguered Lira regaining some poise on increased efforts by the CBRT to stem the tide via direct intervention and ahead of a midday (BST) meeting between the PM and Economy Ministry to discuss currency market developments and the overall state of the economy (Usd/Try back below 4.3000 from 4.3700+ at one stage).

JPY

The biggest G10 loser as the Buck extends its winning streak, with reaction to US President Trump’s withdrawal from the Iranian nuclear accord and threat of severe sanctions largely confined to crude that has spiked higher, and limited risk-aversion or contagion thus far. Hence, Usd/Jpy as bounced firmly from sub-109.00 lows above 109.50 and towards recent peaks just above 110.00, with the 200 DMA and a key Fib (around 110.19 and 110.24 respectively) also lying in wait beyond the big figure.

AUD/CHF

Both around 0.2-0.25% lower vs the Usd, and with the former at risk of losing 0.7400+ status, while the latter is revisiting highs within a 1.0000-50 band despite the Franc maintaining momentum vs the Eur below 1.1900.

EUR

Yet more bearish fundamentals (via Italian and French data misses) to compound the positional and Dollar related downside for the single currency below 1.1850, and having relinquished 1.1900 on Tuesday there is little in the way of technical support before 1.1800 aside from a late December 2017 low (1.1812), though the round number may offer some sentimental respite given that a major Fib sits just below (1.1790).

NZD/GBP/CAD

All holding up relatively well in the face of almost relentless Usd buying (or net daily advances at least), with the Kiwi above 0.6950 ahead of the RBNZ policy gathering tonight and amidst some Nzd/Jpy buy-stops tripped overnight by algos. Cable is keeping afloat of 1.3500 before BoE ‘super’ Thursday as Gbp/Jpy rebounds sharply and further over 148.00 and Eur/Gbp retreats to sub-0.8750, while the Loonie is deriving support from oil prices at fresh post-2014 peaks to ease back from yesterday’s near 1.3000 highs.

SEK/NOK

The Scandi Crowns showed scant reaction to Swedish and Norwegian inflation reports that were in line or slightly softer overall, with the Sek actually extending gains vs the Eur and Nok on tax payment deadline day (former pair as low as 10.4130).

FIXED INCOME

The catalysts are pretty well defined and wide-ranging from supply to oil-fuelled inflation on US-Iran discord, and the technical landscape is also becoming more negative as Bunds edge close to a major chart support level at a fresh Eurex intraday low of 158..52 (-33 ticks on the day) and Gilts breach their nearest downside objective, albeit just and not yet convincingly at 121.67 (-47 ticks). Meanwhile, US Treasuries are just a few ticks off overnight session lows and the curve is steeper as long bond losses approach one full point and the 10 year yield sits firmly at 3%.

COMMODITIES

Oil prices have continued upwards on Wednesday after President Trump confirmed the withdrawal of the US from the Iran nuclear agreement and imposing of sanctions on the nation; WTI and Brent June ’18 futures at USD 71.00 (+2.8%) and USD 76.89 (+2.7%) respectively. Said sanctions could lead to the reduction of oil exports by 200-500k BPD over the next 6 months for the middle-eastern nation, according to UBS.

Gold prices have continued the slide seen on Tuesday (-0.58%), as the USD held strong on higher treasury yields.

Copper currently up 0.4% at USD 6773.50/tonne as Chinese demand remains strong. This demand is not seen in Chinese rebar however, which is currently down for the fourth straight Wednesday, at USD 559.90/t

content: UK debt futures and the STIR strip are taking their cues from bearish counterparts despite more downbeat domestic survey impulses (via BRC sales and REC employment overnight) that should further underpin market expectations for no change in rates by the BoE tomorrow. Gilts have lost grip of the 122.00 handle after an initial print of 122.03 vs yesterday’s 122.14 Liffe close and have been down to 121.82, as Bunds extend their losses to 29 ticks at 158.56, while 3 month contracts are 1-2 ticks adrift. Chart-wise, the 10 year UK benchmark is eyeing 121.70 next on the downside, while the core Eurozone bond has 158.43 in sight, and in cash terms yields are firmer in line with US Treasuries as 3% trades in advance of the refunding, DMO auction and long-end German supply.

DAILY EUROPEAN EQUITY OPENING NEWS
content:
9th May 2018

The Daily European Equity Opening News is uploaded at 0700BST/0100CDT recapping all of the overnight equity news

From 0700BST/0100CDT all equity news will be covered in real time over the audio and headline feed and the full audio rundown will be at 0715BST/0115CDT.

There will be an additional audio rundown at 0750BST/0150CDT recapping any company news which has hit the wires since 0715BST/0115CDT ahead of the European equity open

ASIA

Asia stocks traded mixed after a lacklustre lead from Wall St and as markets digested US President Trump’s decision to withdraw from the Iran nuclear agreement which in turn underpinned oil prices. ASX 200 (+0.2%) was kept afloat as energy names coat-tailed on the upside in oil, although gains were limited by weakness in financials after Australia’s largest lender CBA reported earnings. Elsewhere, Nikkei 225 (-0.4%) failed to benefit from JPY weakness and traded subdued, in which electricity names took a power dive on the higher input costs, while both Shanghai Comp. (+0.1%) and Hang Seng (+0.5%) were initially weaker after a daily net liquidity drain by the PBoC and the verbal spat between US and China envoys at the WTO. However, Chinese markets later recovered with Hong Kong leading the rebound as money market rates eased, in which the 1-month HIBOR declined for a 6th consecutive session.

FTSE

Vodafone (VOD LN) – The co. is nearing a EUR 18bln deal with Liberty Global’s (LBTYA) EU assets. (FT)

Sky (SKY LN) – Disney’s Iger says he remains confident the Fox (FOXA) asset deal will go forward, and says he talks to Fox’s Murdoch on a regular basis. Iger also intends to hold onto at least 39% of Sky it will get even if fox does not get approval to buy the 61% they don’t currently own. (CNBC)

Burberry (BRBY LN) – Belgian tycoon Albert Frère is to sell his whole GBP 520mln shareholding in the co. (Telegraph)

DAX

Siemens (SIE GY) – Q2 orders of EUR 22.32bln vs. Exp. EUR 21.02bln, revenue of EUR 20.14bln vs. Exp. EUR 20.09bln, profit of EUR 2.25bln vs. Exp. EUR 2.07bln. Raises basic EPS outlook for EUR 7.70 to EUR 8 from EUR 7.20 to EUR 7.70. Board member expects FY2018 revenue to be substantially lower than FY2017. (Newswires)

Fraport (FRA GY) – Q1 group revenue EUR 681mln, EBITDA EUR 174.7mln, maintains FY guidance unchanged. (Newswires)

Deutsche Telekom (DTE GY) – Q1 revenue of EUR 17.92bln vs. Exp. EUR 17.98bln, EBITDA EUR 5.55bln vs. Exp. EUR 5.50bln. Raises adj. EBITDA forecast to EUR 23.3bln from EUR 23.2bln. (Newswires)

Volkswagen (VOW3 GY) – Audi aims to produce 800,000 electric cars eyeing more than 20 models in 2025. Targets EUR 20bln cost cuts by 2022 vs. Prev. EUR 10bln. Extends period for EUR 40bln investment from 2022 to 2025. (Newswires)

Deutsche Bank (DBK GY) – The bank is said to consider cutting its US staff by roughly 20%, however the bank did deny this report later on. (Newswires)

Heidelberg Cement (HEI GY) – Q1 RCO loss of EUR 16mln vs. prev. EUR 108mln, RCOBD EUR 252mln vs. prev. EUR 383mln, revenue of EUR 3.68bln vs. prev. EUR 3.78bln. The co. affirms outlook. (Newswires)

Henkel (HEN GY) – Q1 EPS +1.4% to EUR 1.43, sales at EUR 4.835bln, organic growth 1.1%. FY outlook confirmed. (Newswires)

OTHER GERMAN COMPANIES

Wienerberger (WIB GY) – Co. expects a continuation of positive trends seen everywhere, growth path to be continued, FY objectives confirmed. (Newswires)

Brenntag (BNR GY) – Operating gross profit +6.6% on a constant currency basis to EUR 637.6mln. Profit after tax at EUR 106mln and EPS at EUR 0.68. Co. confirms its growth forecast for 2018. (Newswires)

TUI AG (TUI1 GY) – Q2 underlying EBITDA loss of EUR 125.1mln vs. prev. loss of EUR 154mln, revenues of EUR 3.31bln, up 6.3% from prev., add summer trading performance “very good”. (Newswires)

United Internet (UTDI GY) – Q1 revenue EUR 1.27bln vs. Prev. EUR 1.14bln and EBITDA EUR 278.3mln vs. Prev. EUR 256.1mln. (Newswires)

Dialog Semiconductors (DLG GY) – Q1 operating profit +13% to USD 32.9mln, revenue +23% to USD 332mln, anticipate Q2 revenue to be in range of USD 275-305mln. Revenue performance strongly weighted toward second half of year. (Newswires)

BROKER MOVES

ALLIANZ (ALV GY) UPGRADED TO BUY FROM HOLD AT HSBC

HANNOVER RE (HNR1 GY) DOWNFRADED TO REDUCE FROM HOLD AT HSBC

CAC

Airbus (AIR FP) – United Airlines (UAL) reportedly in talks with the co and Boeing (BA) for wide body jets, to replace its fleet of 50 737 jetliners, according to sources. (Newswires)

OTHER FRENCH COMPANIES

PAN EUROPE

AB InBev (ABI BB) – Q1 total volume 134.8 hectolitres vs. Exp. 134 hectolitres. Q1 total revenue USD 13.07bln vs. Exp. USD 12.92bln. Co. expects to deliver strong revenue and EBITDA growth in 2018. Co. remains confident that growth will accelerate for the balance of the year, primarily in the second half. (Newswires)

ING Groep (INGA NA) – Q1 underlying income EUR 4.46bln vs. Exp. EUR 4.37bln, underlying pre-tax result EUR 1.686bln vs. Exp. EUR 1.52bln. Q4 rolling ROE was 10.3%, fully loaded CET1 ratio was 14.3%. On track for EUR 900mln cost saving goal. (Newswires)

Ahold Delhaize (AD NA) – Q1 net income EUR 407mln vs. prev. EUR 241mln, income from underlying operations EUR 600mln vs. Exp. EUR 590mln, revenue of EUR 14.9bln vs. Exp. EUR 14.8bln. (Newswires)

BROKER MOVES

GENERALI (G IM) DOWNGRADED TO HOLD FROM BUY AT HSBC

NN GROUP (NN NA) DOWNGRADED TO HOLD FROM BUY AT HSBC

ITALGAS (IG IM) DOWNGRADED TO HOLD FROM BUY AT SOCGEN

SCANDINAVIA

Genmab (GEN DC) – Q1 revenue at DDK 681mln vs. Prev. DKK 251mln. Operating income DKK 324mln vs. Exp. 684mln. Net profit DKK 198.6mln vs. Exp. DKK 282mln. (Newswires)

Skanksa (SKAB SS) – Q1 revenue +8% at SEK 37.0bln vs. Exp SEK 35.9bln. Q1 operating income down 65% at SEK 0.7bln. (Newswires)

Nokian Tyres (NRE1V FH) – Q1 EBIT at EUR 61.2mln vs. Exp. EUR 69mln, sales at EUR 336mln vs. Exp. EUR 342mln. Says with current exchange rates, net sales and profit is expected to grow vs. 2017. (Newswires)

SMI

Zurich Insurance (ZURN SW) – Q1 P&C GWP USD 9.33bln vs. Prev. USD 8.92bln. Life annual premium at USD 1.25bln vs. Prev. USD 1.17bln. Farmers exchanges GWP USD 5.12bln vs. Prev. USD 4.94bln. Z-ECM 133% vs. Prev. 132%. (Newswires)

BROKER MOVES

ADECCO (ADEN SW) UPGRADED TO HOLD FROM UNDERPERFORM AT JEFFERIES

SWISS LIFE HOLDINGS (SLHN SW) UPGRADED TO HOLD FROM REDUCE AT HSBC

US

US Equity futures started off on the backfoot as markets awaited Trump’s decision on the nuclear deal, but mixed source reports resulted in choppy trade until it was confirmed Trump is to pull out of the deal, resulting in a slightly risk off tone. However, this changed heading into the close where some of the earlier losses were pared back. Telecoms underperformed in Tuesday trade following earnings from Dish (DISH) where revenue fell short, and the co. saw a net decline of roughly 94,000 Pay TV customers, and its average monthly subscriber rate for Dish TV was at 1.47%, lower than the 1.92% for Q1 of 2017.

SECTORS: Cons Cyclicals: -0.46%, Cons Non-Cyclicals: -0.46%, Energy: +0.78%, Financials: +0.69%, Health Care: -0.78%, Industrials: +0.72%, Materials: -0.26%, Technology: +0.29%, Telecoms: -1.29%, Utilities: -2.52%.

subject: DAILY EUROPEAN OPENING NEWS: US President Trump announced the US is to pull out of the Iran nuclear deal and will institute 'highest level' of sanctions on Iran
content:
US President Trump announced the US is to pull out of the Iran nuclear deal and will institute 'highest level' of sanctions on Iran

Asia stocks traded mixed after a lacklustre lead from Wall St. USD firmer with the DXY above 93.00 and at a fresh YTD high amid rising US yields

Looking ahead, highlights include Norwegian and Swedish CPI, US PPI, DoEs, Fed’s Bostic, RBNZ and US 10yr Auction

IRAN NUCLEAR AGREEMENT

US President Trump announced the US is to pull out of the Iran nuclear deal and will institute 'highest level' of sanctions on Iran. Trump added that the deal should never have been made and has allowed Iran to continue to enrich uranium, while he stated the US is to be ready, willing and able to renegotiate a deal with Iran. (Newswires)

US Treasury Department said oil related sanctions on Iran are to be re-imposed in 180 days and US Treasury Secretary Mnuchin said that effectively sanctions will be going into place immediately. Furthermore, Mnuchin also commented that the US will be working with allies on a comprehensive deal and that firms can seek waivers or special licences to operate in Iran. (Newswires)

French President Macron noted that France will work collectively on a broader framework, covering nuclear activity, the post-2025 period, ballistic activity, and stability in the Middle-East, notably Syria, Yemen, and Iraq. Furthermore, there were also comments by EU’s Mogherimi that the EU vows to uphold Iran nuclear accord despite Trump’s decision. (Twitter/Newswires)

Iran's leader Rouhani said Iran is committed to its own and confirmed that Iran will continue the nuclear deal with members of the P5+1 even without US, while Rouhani added he is ready to resume nuclear work following talks with EU members of the deal. (State TV/Newswires)

There was volatility in crude prices with the rumour mill rife in the hours leading to the announcement. WTI crude initially fell around USD 2 to below USD 68/bbl amid CNN reports that US President Trump is to announce new sanctions against Iran and will not withdraw from the deal. However, the weakness was then pared on conflicting reports that President Trump decided to pull-out of the agreement which was later confirmed and underpinned WTI crude back above USD 70/bbl. (Newswires)

ASIA

Asia stocks traded mixed after a lacklustre lead from Wall St and as markets digested US President Trump’s decision to withdraw from the Iran nuclear agreement which in turn underpinned oil prices. ASX 200 (+0.2%) was kept afloat as energy names coat-tailed on the upside in oil, although gains were limited by weakness in financials after Australia’s largest lender CBA reported earnings. Elsewhere, Nikkei 225 (-0.4%) failed to benefit from JPY weakness and traded subdued, in which electricity names took a power dive on the higher input costs, while both Shanghai Comp. (+0.1%) and Hang Seng (+0.5%) were initially weaker after a daily net liquidity drain by the PBoC and the verbal spat between US and China envoys at the WTO. However, Chinese markets later recovered with Hong Kong leading the rebound as money market rates eased, in which the 1-month HIBOR declined for a 6th consecutive session. Finally, 10yr JGBs were uneventful despite the cautious risk tone and BoJ’s presence in the market for over JPY 1tln in 1yr-10yr JGBs. This was amid gains in yields which tracked upside in their US counterparts with the US 10yr yield homing in again on the 3.000% level.

PBoC injected CNY 60bln via 7-day and CNY 40bln via 14-day reverse repos for a net daily drain of CNY 100bln. (Newswires)
PBoC set CNY mid-point at 6.3733 (Prev. 6.3674)

UK/EU

The UK Government has suffered an unexpected Brexit defeat in the Lords, as peers backed retaining key aspects of the EU's single market through continued participation in the European Economic Area. Lords also backed an amendment to remove the Brexit date of 29 March 2019 from the legislation. (Sky News)

Eurosceptic ministers are reported to be worried that UK PM May could bypass her Brexit war cabinet and ask the full cabinet for support regarding a customs partnership with the EU. (Telegraph)

Initially, party sources reported Forza Italia are to consider stepping back to allow a 5-Star/League government, however this was later denied by Berlusconi. (Newswires)

UK BRC Sales Like-For-Like (Apr) Y/Y -4.2% vs. Exp. -0.8% (Prev. 1.4%). (Newswires)

FX

USD was firmer with the DXY above the 93.00 level and at a fresh YTD high amid rising US yields. This dampened price action across its major counterparts, while the PBoC also weakened its reference rate in response. USD/JPY was higher after support at the 109.00 level eventually held and amid cross-related flows in which GBP/JPY reclaimed the 148.00 handle and with algo-short covering said to have been triggered in NZD/JPY. Elsewhere, AUD and NZD lacked any substantial drivers with the latter subdued ahead of today’s RBNZ policy meeting, in which expectations are one-sided for no change in rates and with the scope for tighter policy also restricted by ongoing soft inflation.

COMMODITIES

Commodities were mixed with crude prices ultimately higher after President Trump confirmed the withdrawal of the US from the Iran nuclear agreement which helped oil recover from the initial rumour-triggered volatility, with WTI crude futures back above USD 70/bbl while Brent crude gained around 2% to move closer to USD 77/bbl. Elsewhere, gold prices declined as the greenback held firm and copper was flat alongside an indecisive risk tone in the region.

US API weekly Crude Stocks (4 May) -1.850M vs. Exp. -0.700M (Prev. +3.427M). (Newswires)

Saudi Arabia Energy Ministry said they will coordinate efforts with Opec+ to mitigate the impact of any potential oil supply shortfall on market stability. (Newswires)

EIA cut forecast for 2018 world oil demand growth by 30k bpd and now sees 1.76mln bpd increase, while it raised 2018 US crude output estimate to 10.72mln bpd from 10.69mln bpd. (Newswires)

GEOPOLITICAL

US President Trump and China's Xi agreed on a phone call that sanctions on North Korea will remain in place until it permanently dismantles nuclear programmes, according to the White House. (Newswires)

US Secretary of State Pompeo is expected to return from North Korea with 3 detainees, according to South Korean press reports. (Yonhap)
US

Treasuries were lower on Tuesday with most of the action concentrated in the front end and belly of the curve. The 5yr yield was up by c.3bps, the 2yr and 10yr yields were higher by c.2bps. The Treasury auctioned USD 31bln in 3yr notes with a tail of 0.1bps. The yield came in at 2.664%, the highest since May 2007. Dealers were left with the largest proportion of the issuance at 42.2%, well above the 6-auction average. Directs were awarded 12.3% and indirect 14.6%, the smallest portion since July 2016. US 10yr T-Notes futures settle 5+ ticks lower at 119-16+.

ASIA-PAC MARKET WRAP:  Asia stocks traded indecisive and oil gained as markets digested US withdrawal from the Iran nuclear agreement
content: Asia stocks traded mixed after a lacklustre lead from Wall St and as markets digested US President Trump’s decision to withdraw from the Iran nuclear agreement which in turn underpinned oil prices. ASX 200 (+0.2%) was kept afloat as energy names coat-tailed on the upside in oil, although gains were limited by weakness in financials after Australia’s largest lender CBA reported earnings in which it noted a slight decline in group net interest margin and that underlying operating expenses were higher due to provisions. Elsewhere, Nikkei 225 (-0.4%) failed to benefit from JPY weakness and traded subdued, in which electricity names took a power dive on the higher input costs, while both Shanghai Comp. (+0.1%) and Hang Seng (+0.5%) were initially weaker after a daily net liquidity drain by the PBoC and the verbal spat between US and China envoys at the WTO. However, Chinese markets later recovered with Hong Kong leading the rebound as money market rates eased, in which the 1-month HIBOR declined for a 6th consecutive session. Finally, 10yr JGBs were uneventful despite the cautious risk tone and BoJ’s presence in the market for over JPY 1tln in 1yr-10yr JGBs. This was amid gains in yields which tracked upside in their US counterparts with the US 10yr yield homing in again on the 3.000% level.

ASIA-PAC MID-SESSION UPDATE: Asia stocks trade lacklustre as region digests Trump's withdrawal from Iran nuclear agreement
content:
Asia stocks trade indecisive after a lacklustre lead from Wall St and as markets digest US President Trump’s decision to withdraw from the Iran nuclear agreement which in turn underpinned oil prices. ASX 200 (Unch) is just about kept afloat with energy names benefiting from the upside in oil, although gains are limited by weakness in financials after Australia’s largest lender CBA reported earnings in which it noted a slight decline in group net interest margin and that underlying operating expenses were higher due to provisions. Elsewhere, Nikkei 225 (-0.4%) is subdued and fails to benefit from JPY weakness with electricity names taking a power dive on the higher input costs, while both Shanghai Comp. (-0.3%) and Hang Seng (Unch) are also uninspiring after a substantial daily net liquidity drain by the PBoC and the verbal spat between US and China envoys at the WTO.

In FX markets, USD is firmer with the DXY above the 93.00 level and at a fresh YTD high amid rising US yields, which has dampened price action across its major counterparts and the PBoC also weakened its reference rate in response. USD/JPY is higher after support at the 109.00 level eventually held and amid cross-related flows in which GBP/JPY reclaimed the 148.00 handle and with algo-short covering said to have been triggered in NZD/JPY. Elsewhere, AUD and NZD lack any substantial drivers with the latter subdued ahead of tomorrow’s RBNZ policy meeting, in which expectations are one-sided for no change in rates and with the scope for tighter policy also restricted by ongoing soft inflation.

Finally, 10yr JGBs are lacklustre and have failed to benefit from the cautious risk tone and BoJ’s presence in the market for over JPY 1tln in 1yr-10yr JGBs. This is amid gains in yields which track upside in their US counterparts with the US 10yr yield homing in again on the 3.000% level.
